name: SCANDINAVIAN DEFENSE
idea: The simplest response to 1.e4! Black immediately attacks the e4 pawn with ...d5. After 2.exd5 Qxd5 3.Nc3, the Queen must move but Black develops quickly. The modern approach is ...Qa5 (keeping the Queen active) or ...Qd6 (defending d5). It's an opening with very little theory - Black knows the positions better than most White players. Perfect for club players who want practical chances!
errors_white: Playing without a plan: Nc3, Nf3, d4, Bc4 is the standard setup
Trying to 'punish' Black: the Scandinavian is sound, play normal chess
Overestimating the Queen move: Black develops quickly after ...Qa5
errors_black: Playing ...Qxd5 then ...Qa5 without a plan: the Queen must find a good square
Forgetting development: ...Nf6, ...Bf5/...Bg4, ...e6, ...c6 is the standard setup
Playing ...Nf6 gambits without knowing the theory: can backfire
development: After Qxd5 Nc3, retreat to a5 (aggressive) or d6 (solid) - never d8!
It's the key piece! Develop to f5 (classical) or g4 (pins the Nf3)
Nf6 attacks e4 and develops, Nc6/Nd7 supports the center
...c6 is essential to support d5 and prepare ...e6 or ...e5
Develop to e7 (solid) or g7 after ...g6 (fianchetto)

traps.name: Queen Trap
traps.desc: After 2...Qxd5 3.Nc3 Qa5 4.d4?? ...Qxd1+? No! 4...e5! and if 5.dxe5?? Qxe5+ wins a piece. AVOID (White): Play Nf3 or Bd2 before d4.

traps.name: Gambit Trap
traps.desc: 2...Nf6 (gambit) 3.d4?? ...Nxd5! Recovers the pawn with good play. AVOID (White): Play 3.Bb5+ or 3.c4 to keep the pawn or complicate.

traps.name: Portuguese Trap
traps.desc: Portuguese Variation: 3...Qa5 4.d4 Nf6 5.g4?? (chases the Bishop) ...Bxc2! wins the c2 pawn since the Queen defends. AVOID (White): Don't play g4 - develop normally with Nf3.

variants.name: Modern Variation (Qa5)
variants.uci: e2e4 d7d5 e4d5 d8d5 b1c3 d5a5 d2d4 g8f6
variants.white_plan: Develop Nf3, Bd2 (defends c3 and prepares Bc4), 0-0. Keep central pressure with a space advantage.
variants.black_plan: Play ...Bf5! (develop the Bishop before ...e6), then ...c6, ...e6, ...Nbd7, ...Be7 and castle. Solid position.

variants.name: Classical Variation (Qd6)
variants.uci: e2e4 d7d5 e4d5 d8d5 b1c3 d5d6 d2d4 g8f6
variants.white_plan: Develop Nf3, Bd3 or Bc4, 0-0. The d4 center is strong. Look to open the game to exploit the development advantage.
variants.black_plan: The Queen on d6 is solid but passive. Play ...a6 (prepares ...b5), ...Bf5, ...c6 then ...e6 and castle.

variants.name: Scandinavian Gambit (Nf6)
variants.uci: e2e4 d7d5 e4d5 g8f6 d2d4 f6d5 c2c4 d5b6
variants.white_plan: Powerful c4-d4 center. Develop Nf3, Nc3, Bd3 and 0-0. The position is very comfortable for White.
variants.black_plan: Counter-attack the center! ...g6 and ...Bg7 (fianchetto) or ...Bf5, ...e6, ...Be7. The Nb6 targets c4 and d5.
